text:
Noor Ahmad won the Man of the Match award in the Chennai Super Kings vs Mumbai Indians match in IPL 2025 on March 23. The Afghanistan spinner, acquired by Chennai Super Kings for Rs 10 crore at the IPL 2025 auction, made a mark playing his first match for the five-time champions, taking four wickets including two in an over. Noor Ahmad's victims were Mumbai Indians' stand-in captain Suryakumar Yadav (29), Tilak Varma (31), Robin Minz (3) and Naman Dhir (17). He finished with figures of 4/18 in his four overs, which also included 12 dot balls. MS Dhoni Pulls Off Lightning-Fast Stumping To Dismiss Suryakumar Yadav During CSK vs MI IPL 2025 Match (Watch Video).

title: Noor Ahmad Wins Man of the Match Award in CSK vs MI IPL 2025 Match
description:
The Afghanistan wrist spinner showed why he was such a special cricketer with a memorable performance on his debut for the five-time champions. Noor Ahmad previously played for Gujarat Titans in the IPL.

text:
New Zealand seal a 3-1 victory in the five-match T20I series against Pakistan after they secured a comfortable 115-run victory in the 4th T20I at Bay Oval, Mount Maunganui. Coming into the game after winning the last match at Eden Park, Pakistan was expected to go hard on New Zealand but unlike last time, the New Zealand openers Tim Seifert and Finn Allen gave New Zealand a solid start. Haris Rauf and Abrar Ahmed helped Pakistan make a comeback in the middle overs, but Michael Bracewell's solid finish powered New Zealand over 200 to a score of 220/6. Chasing it, Pakistan went nowhere as they kept losing wickets. Zakary Foulkes scalped three wickets and Jacob Duffy picked a four-wicket haul as Pakistan crumbled to 9/3 and then 56/8 in no time. It was a very comfortable victory for New Zealand in the end and they have now sealed the series with one match to spare. Pakistan Funny Memes and Jokes Go Viral As Visitors Lose Three Wickets for Just Nine Runs in Pursuit of 221During NZ vs PAK 4th T20I 2025.
New Zealand Defeat Pakistan by 115 Runs in 4th T20I 2025
A big win at Bay Oval secures the KFC T20I series with a game to spare! Jacob Duffy (4-20) and Zak Foulkes (3-25) leading the way with the ball. The final match of the series is in Wellington on Wednesday. title: New Zealand Defeat Pakistan by 115 Runs in 4th T20I 2025; Finn Allen's Half-Century, Jacob Duffy's Four-Wicket Haul Helps Kiwis Seal 3-1 Series Victory
description: With the win in the fourth T20I, New Zealand have taken an unassailable 3-1 lead in the five-match T20I series against Pakistan. This win came after they lost the last match at Eden Park. ğŸ New Zealand Defeat Pakistan by 115 Runs in 4th T20I 2025; Finn Allen's Half-Century, Jacob Duffy's Four-Wicket Haul Helps Kiwis Seal 3-1 Series Victory.

text:
TORONTO â€” Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney on Sunday called a snap federal election, seeking to capitalize on momentum that has his Liberals resurgent. The campaign is likely to come down to one question: Who can best handle President Donald Trump and make Canada more resilient in the face of his threats?

Carney requested that the governor-general dissolve Parliament, which was to begin Monday, and set elections for April 28. By law, an election had to be held by Oct. 20, but a prime minister may request Parliamentâ€™s dissolution at any time, and opposition parties had vowed to bring the government down.

A former central banker and political rookie, Carney, 60, won the Liberal leadership this month and was sworn in as prime minister on March 14. The federal election will pit him against Conservative Party leader Pierre Poilievre, 45, a populist firebrand who until recently held a commanding lead in the polls.

Advertisement

The 37-day campaign, the minimum required by law, follows domestic political upheaval. In January, Justin Trudeau announced he would step down as Liberal leader and prime minister, amid a caucus mutiny set in motion by the abrupt resignation of his deputy prime minister from his cabinet.

It also comes at a time of great anxiety here as Canadaâ€™s bond with the United States, a NATO ally and its largest trading partner, is rupturing â€” with profound consequences for the countryâ€™s economy, society and place in the world.

Trump has levied and threatened tariffs on Canadian goods that could plunge Canadaâ€™s economy into a recession. He has vowed to use â€œeconomic forceâ€ to annex Canada and mused repeatedly about redrawing the U.S.-Canada border.

Speaking to reporters in Ottawa on Sunday, Carney said he needed â€œa strong, positive mandate.â€

Advertisement

â€œWe are facing the most significant crisis of our lifetimes because of President Trumpâ€™s unjustified trade actions and threats to our sovereignty,â€ he said. â€œOur response must be to build a strong economy and a more secure Canada.â€

Trump â€œclaims that Canada isnâ€™t a real country,â€ he added. â€œHe wants to break us so America can own us. We will not let that happen.â€

Poilievre on Sunday blamed a â€œlost Liberal decadeâ€ and a â€œradical, post-national, borderless order with a globalist ideologyâ€ for cementing underlying weaknesses that have left Canada more vulnerable in the face of Trumpâ€™s threats.

â€œThe question is whether Canadians can afford a fourth Liberal term,â€ he told reporters. â€œOr is it time to put Canada first for a change with a new Conservative government that will ax taxes, honor hard work, build homes ... lock up criminals, secure our borders, unleash resources to bring home our jobs and stand up to Donald Trump from a position of strength?â€

Trumpâ€™s actions have infuriated Canadians â€” and upended their politics.

Before Trudeauâ€™s resignation and Trumpâ€™s return, the Liberals were headed for a potentially historic trouncing and had trailed the Conservatives for more than a year. Since then, in a rapid swing that pollsters say has few parallels here, the Conservativesâ€™ 20-point lead has vanished, and the race is competitive. Some polls show the Liberals ahead.

Advertisement

â€œPrior to January, there was a story: There was a villain, and that villain was Justin Trudeau, and the hero was Pierre Poilievre,â€ said David Coletto, chair of pollster Abacus Data. â€œNow, the villain in most Canadiansâ€™ minds is Donald Trump, but weâ€™re still figuring out who the hero will be.â€

Carney, a former Goldman Sachs banker, drew praise for his leadership of the Bank of Canada during the global financial crisis and the Bank of England during Brexit. He is seeking to cast himself as the unflappable, experienced crisis manager that Canada needs at one of the most turbulent moments in its modern history.

Since his swearing-in as prime minister, he has traveled to Britain and France to deepen ties with â€œreliable alliesâ€ and has scrapped several Trudeau government policies, including a consumer carbon tax.

Advertisement

Carney, who is also an ex-chair of Brookfield Asset Management, placed his assets in a blind trust after the leadership vote, and has faced scrutiny about what those assets were before they were divested. He has bristled at the questions, telling a reporter who pressed him about possible conflicts of interest to â€œlook inside yourself.â€

â€œIâ€™m complying with all the rules,â€ he said last week.

Carney supported dollar-for-dollar retaliatory tariffs during the Liberal leadership campaign and pledged to keep the levies in place â€œuntil the Americans show us respect.â€ Last week, he said there is â€œa limitâ€ to such reprisals because Canadaâ€™s economy is smaller than its neighborâ€™s.

While he is known in the world of finance, Carney remains an undefined figure to many Canadians and has no experience in elected politics. His stumbles in speaking French could be a liability. He is not considered to be a stirring speaker and has never been through the wringer of a federal election campaign.

Advertisement

â€œTo use a sports analogy, the leadership race was basically the warm-up and the general election is the playoffs,â€ Coletto said. â€œThereâ€™s been no regular season for Mark Carney.â€

In rÃ©sumÃ© and style, Poilievre presents a stark contrast.

Poilievre is a lifelong politician who rose to prominence as a smarmy attack dog in Parliament. He became party leader in 2022, vowing to fight â€œgatekeepersâ€ and championing the anti-government â€œFreedom Convoyâ€ blockades.

He gained support by zeroing in on inflation, grocery prices that are forcing middle-class families to visit food banks, and high housing costs that have left many millennials frustrated â€” laying the blame, fairly or not, at Trudeauâ€™s feet.

He uses catchy slogans: â€œAx the [carbon] tax, build the homes, fix the budget, stop the crime.â€ And he has often attacked reporters, announcing last week that he will block them from traveling on his campaign plane and bus for logistical reasons.

Advertisement

Analysts say Poilievre has not adapted well to the changes wrought by Trumpâ€™s return, Trudeauâ€™s resignation and Carneyâ€™s ascendance. As Trumpâ€™s attacks animate a rally-around-the-flag moment, Poilievreâ€™s message â€” that â€œCanada is brokenâ€ â€” no longer resonates, and his efforts to slam Carney as â€œjust like Justinâ€ arenâ€™t sticking.

â€œThey need to pivot big-time because the question isnâ€™t Trudeau anymore,â€ said Lori Turnbull, chair of the public and international affairs department at Dalhousie University.

Poilievre also supports retaliatory tariffs. At a â€œCanada Firstâ€ rally last month, he vowed to â€œbear any burden and pay any price to protect our sovereignty and independence.â€

The Liberals have cast Poilievreâ€™s party as â€œwannabe MAGA maple syrup Conservatives,â€ rolling out ads that cut between Trump and Poilievre using identical language.

Advertisement

One challenge for the Conservative leader, analysts said, is that while mainstream voters here do not support the U.S. president, there is a faction of Conservative voters who do, and talking tough on Trump could alienate them.

In a break with the tradition of U.S. presidents congratulating new Canadian prime ministers, Trump has not issued a statement about Carney. But he has weighed in on Canadaâ€™s domestic politics several times, offering contradictory messages.

In January, he said on â€œThe Hugh Hewitt Showâ€ that it would be â€œvery goodâ€ if Poilievre won, because their views are â€œmore aligned.â€ Pressed last week on how his threats against Canada are resurrecting the Liberals, he told Fox News that Poilievre is â€œstupidly no friend of mine.â€

â€œI think itâ€™s easier to deal, actually, with a liberal,â€ Trump said, â€œand maybe theyâ€™re going to win, but I donâ€™t really care.â€

Advertisement

Canadians do not vote directly for prime minister. Instead, voters in each of the 343 electoral districts, known as ridings, vote for a member of Parliament. If a party wins a majority of the seats, it forms the government and its leader is prime minister. In a minority government, the ruling party must rely on opposition support to stay in power.

Coletto said Canadians are looking for a leader to bring â€œstabilityâ€ in a Trump-fueled storm.
title: Canadaâ€™s Carney calls snap election as Trump looms over campaign
